content: The Act titled "Provisional Ballot Fairness in Counting Act of 2007" establishes a uniform standard for the treatment of provisional ballots cast at incorrect polling places. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to ensure that provisional ballots of eligible registered voters in a State are counted in Federal elections if certain conditions are met. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to ensure that provisional ballots of eligible registered voters in a State are counted in Federal elections if the individual is registered to vote in the Congressional district where the provisional ballot is cast. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to specify the minimum contents of provisional ballots for Federal elections and the treatment of voters who cast their votes after polling places close. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to ensure equal treatment for voters who cast their ballots after polling places close, following court orders or state laws. Provisional ballots must be treated the same as ballots cast during regular polling hours. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to require election officials to notify individuals of the eligibility of their provisional ballot within 24 hours, including reasons for any determination that the vote will not be counted and the right to challenge the decision. Each state must establish procedures for this notification process. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 now requires election officials to notify individuals of their provisional ballot eligibility within 24 hours, including reasons for non-counting and the right to challenge. States must ensure open office hours for voters to challenge determinations after the election. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandates election officials to inform individuals of their provisional ballot eligibility within 24 hours, providing reasons for non-counting and the right to challenge. The chief State election official is prohibited from making any determination on recount applicability before reviewing provisional ballots. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 requires election officials to inform individuals of their provisional ballot eligibility within 24 hours, provide reasons for non-counting, and the right to challenge. The chief State election official cannot conduct a recount or certify election results until all provisional ballots are counted. The official must review not only the Statewide list of registered voters but also any additional information provided by the individual during voter registration. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandates that election officials notify individuals of their provisional ballot eligibility within 24 hours, provide reasons for non-counting, and the right to challenge. If a provisional ballot is rejected due to lack of voter registration, it will be treated as an application for registration under the same terms and conditions. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 requires states to comply with new requirements starting January 1, 2004, with certain provisions applying to elections from November 2008 onwards.
